revision.text:
{{Year box}} [[Image:Charlotte Cooper.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Wimbledon tennis champion [[Charlotte Cooper Sterry]]]] '''1901 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== '''Professional championships''' * [[Western Pennsylvania Professional Football Circuit|Western Pennsylvania Championship]] – [[1901 Homestead Library & Athletic Club football team|Homestead Library & Athletic Club]]
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * [[The Football League]] – [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] 45 points, [[Sunderland FC|Sunderland]] 43, [[Notts County]] 40, [[Nottingham Forest]] 39, [[Bury FC|Bury]] 39, [[Newcastle United]] 38 * [[1901 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Tottenham Hotspur]] 3–1 [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] at [[Crystal Palace National Sports Centre|Crystal Palace]], London (replay following 2–2 draw at Crystal Palace). * Tottenham Hotspur is the first (and to date only) [[non-League football|non-League]] club to win the FA Cup since the foundation of the Football League. * [[Brighton & Hove Albion FC]] founded. '''Hungary''' * Formation of the [[Hungarian Football Federation]] (i.e., the Magyar Labdarúgó Szövetség or MLSZ) '''Peru''' * [[Alianza Lima]], officially founded on February 15.{{citation needed|date=February 2016}} '''Scotland''' * [[Scottish Football League]] – [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] * [[1901 Scottish Cup Final|Scottish Cup final]] – [[Heart of Midlothian F.C.|Hearts]] 4–3 [[Glasgow Celtic|Celtic]] at [[Ibrox Stadium|Ibrox Park]]
==[[Athletics (sport)|Athletics]]== * [[Jack Caffery (track and field athlete)|Jack Caffery]] wins the fifth running of the [[Boston Marathon]].<ref name="BAA 1901-1905">{{cite web |url=http://www.baa.org/races/boston-marathon/boston-marathon-history/race-summaries/1901-1905.aspx |title=Boston Marathon History: 1901-1905 |first= |last= |author=Boston Athletic Association |authorlink=Boston Athletic Association |coauthors= |date= |month= |year=2011 |work=www.baa.org |publisher=Boston Athletic Association |location=Boston |page= |pages= |at= |language= |trans-title=|format= |doi= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |accessdate=March 2, 2011 |quote= |ref= |separator= |postscript=}}</ref>
==[[Australian rules football]]== '''VFL Premiership''' * [[Essendon Football Club|Essendon]] wins the 5th [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership – Essendon 6.7 (43) d [[Collingwood Football Club|Collingwood]] 2.4 (16) at [[Lake Oval]]
==[[Baseball]]== '''National championship''' * [[National League]] championship – [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] * [[American League]] championship – [[Chicago White Sox]] '''Events''' * The [[American League]] repudiates its minor status and competes with the [[National League]] as a second major league. The AL abandons four western cities for Washington, Baltimore, Philadelphia and Boston. It signs about 30 prominent NL players before the season begins. * The [[National League]] violates its constitution in the summer and there will be no major-minor agreement until the [[1903 in baseball|1903 season]]. * December – numerous minor leagues establish their own National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, commonly called [[Minor League Baseball]] (1902 to date).
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * [[Barbados Joe Walcott]] wins the [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship. He is ranked by [[Nat Fleischer]] and [[Charley Rose]] as the #1 All-Time Welterweight; other sports personalities such as [[Tad Dorgan]], [[Tom O'Rourke (boxing manager)|Tom O'Rourke]], [[Dan Morgan (boxing manager)|Dan Morgan]] and [[Jimmy Johnston]] call him "the greatest pound for pound fighter who ever lived".<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/walcott-j.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Barbados Joe Walcott]</ref> * [[Young Corbett II]] wins the [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship, defeating [[Terry McGovern (boxer)|"Terrible" Terry McGovern]] with a second round knockout * The vacant [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship is claimed first by [[Harry Harris (boxer)|Harry Harris]], who fails to defend it and increases his weight, so making himself ineligible. The title is then awarded to [[Harry Forbes]] following his second round knockout of Danny Dougherty '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[James J. Jeffries]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Tommy Ryan]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[William "Matty" Matthews]] → [[James "Rube" Ferns]] → [[Barbados Joe Walcott]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Frank Erne]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Terry McGovern (boxer)|"Terrible" Terry McGovern]] → [[Young Corbett II]] * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – title vacant → [[Harry Harris (boxer)|Harry Harris]] → title vacant → [[Harry Forbes]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * No cricket is played in South Africa due to the [[Boer War]]. '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club|Yorkshire]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – [[Durham County Cricket Club|Durham]] * Most runs – [[Bobby Abel]] 3309 @ 55.15 (HS 247) * Most wickets – [[Wilfred Rhodes]] 251 @ 15.12 (BB 8–53) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year]] – [[Len Braund]], [[Charlie McGahey]], [[Frank Mitchell (sportsman born 1872)|Frank Mitchell]], [[Willie Quaife]], [[Johnny Tyldesley]] '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – [[Victoria cricket team|Victoria]] * Most runs – [[Clem Hill]] 620 @ 103.33 (HS 365*) * Most wickets – [[Jack Saunders (cricketer, born 1876)|Jack Saunders]] 29 @ 17.13 (BB 6–70) and [[Joe Travers]] 29 @ 20.75 (BB 9–30) '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular|Bombay Presidency]] – [[Parsees cricket team|Parsees]] '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – not contested '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – [[Trinidad and Tobago cricket team|Trinidad and Tobago]]
==[[Figure skating]]== '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * [[1901 World Figure Skating Championships|World Men's Champion]] – [[Ulrich Salchow]] (Sweden)
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1901 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[James Braid (golfer)|James Braid]] * [[1901 US Open (golf)|US Open]] – [[Willie Anderson (golfer)|Willie Anderson]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[Harold Hilton]] * [[United States Amateur Championship (men's golf)|US Amateur]] – [[Walter Travis]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[Grand National]] – Grudon * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Aida (horse)|Aida]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Handicapper (horse)|Handicapper]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Volodyovski]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Cap and Bells II]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Doricles]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Revenue '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – John Ruskin '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Tipperary Boy * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Carrigavalla '''USA''' * [[1901 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – His Eminence * [[Preakness Stakes]] – [[The Parader]] * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Commando
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Stanley Cup''' * [[Winnipeg Victorias]] defeats defending champion [[Montreal Shamrocks]] in a Cup challenge, two games to nil * Winnipeg Victorias wins the [[Manitoba Hockey Association]] (MHA) title over the Winnipeg Hockey Club and successfully defends the Stanley Cup title * [[Ottawa Hockey Club]] wins the [[Canadian Amateur Hockey League]] (CAHL) championship but declines to challenge Winnipeg for the Stanley Cup
==[[Lacrosse]]== '''Events''' * [[Donald Mann|Sir Donald Mann]] donates the [[Mann Cup]]. * [[Gilbert Elliot-Murray-Kynynmound, 4th Earl of Minto|Lord Minto]], the [[Governor General of Canada]], donates the [[Minto Cup]]. * Ottawa Capitals win the first [[Mann Cup]] and the first [[Minto Cup]].
==[[Motor racing]]== '''Paris–Berlin Trail''' * The Paris–Berlin Trail is run on 27–29 June over 1105 km and won by [[Henri Fournier]] (France) driving a [[Mors (automobile)|Mors]] in a time of 15:33:06. The race is in retrospect sometimes referred to as the ''VI Grand Prix de l'ACF''.<ref name="TD"/> '''Paris–Bordeaux Trail''' * The Paris–Bordeaux Trail is run on 29 May over 527.1 km and won by [[Henri Fournier]] (France) driving a [[Mors (automobile)|Mors]] in a time of 6:10:44. The race incorporates the Gordon Bennett Cup (see below).<ref name="TD">[http://www.teamdan.com/archive/gen/upto1903/1901.html 1901 Grand Prix and Paris Races]. Retrieved on 7 September 2009.</ref> '''Gordon Bennett Cup''' * The second [[Gordon Bennett Cup in auto racing|Gordon Bennett Cup]] is run from Paris to Bordeaux in conjunction with the Paris–Bordeaux Trail (see above) and won by Léonce Girardot (France) driving a [[Panhard|Panhard-Levassor]]. '''Circuit du Sud-Ouest''' * The ''[[Pau Grand Prix#History|Circuit du Sud-Ouest]]'' was run in Pau. Some [[English language|anglophone]] sources wrongly call it the 'Pau Grand Prix'. This may stem from a mistranslation of the contemporary French sources such as the magazine ''La France Auto'' of March 1901.<ref name="La France Auto Mar 1901">[http://forums.autosport.com/lofiversion/index.php/t57839.html Autosport, The Nostalgia Forum, Robert Dick quoting (translating) from ''La France Automobile'', March 1901]</ref> It was run in four classes around the streets of Pau. The ''Grand Prix du Palais d’Hiver'' was the name of the prizes awarded for the lesser classes ('Light cars' and 'Voiturettes'). The ''Grand Prix de Pau'' was the name of the prize awarded for the 'Heavy' (fastest) class. Thus [[Maurice Farman]] was awarded the 'Grand Prix de Pau' for his overall victory in the ''Circuit du Sud-Ouest'' driving a [[Panhard|Panhard 24 hp]]. Additionally the ''Grand Prix du Palais d’Hiver'' (400 à 650 kg 'Light car' class) was awarded to [[Henri Farman]] ([[Darracq and Company London|Darracq]]); the second ''Grand Prix du Palais d’Hiver'' for the under 400 kg ''Voiturettes''class was awarded to [[Louis Renault (industrialist)|Louis Renault]] ([[Renault]]); the ''Prix du Béarn'' was awarded to Osmont in a '[[De Dion-Bouton|De Dion]]' tricycle.<ref> ([http://forums.autosport.com/lofiversion/index.php/t57839.html Autosport, The Nostalgia Forum, Robert Dick quoting (translating) from ''La France Automobile'', March 1901] ([http://www.kolumbus.fi/leif.snellman/gpw1.htm ''Grand Prix Winners 1895–1949'' by Hans Etzrodt Part 1 1895–1916])</ref>
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 30 March — [[Oxford University Boat Club|Oxford]] wins the 58th [[The Boat Race 1901|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby league]]== '''England''' * [[Rugby Football League Championship|Championship]] – ''not contested'' * [[Challenge Cup|Challenge Cup final]] – [[Batley Bulldogs|Batley]] 6–0 [[Warrington Wolves|Warrington]] at [[Headingley Rugby Stadium]], [[Leeds]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Lancashire League Championship]] – [[Oldham R.L.F.C.|Oldham]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Yorkshire League Championship]] – [[Bradford Park Avenue A.F.C.|Bradford F.C.]]
==[[Rugby union]]== '''Home Nations Championship''' * 19th [[1901 Home Nations Championship|Home Nations Championship]] series is won by [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland]]
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * [[1901 World Allround Speed Skating Championships|Men's All-round Champion]] – Franz Frederik Wathén (Russia)
==[[Tennis]]== '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Arthur Gore (tennis)|Arthur Gore]] (GB) defeats [[Reginald Doherty]] (GB) 4–6 7–5 6–4 6–4 * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Charlotte Cooper Sterry]] defeats [[Blanche Bingley Hillyard]] 6–2 6–2 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[André Vacherot]] defeats [[Paul Lebreton]]: details unknown * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – [[P. Girod]] defeats Leroux (scores unknown) '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[William Larned]] defeats [[Beals Wright]] 6–2 6–8 6–4 6–4 * [[US Open (tennis)|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Elisabeth Moore]] defeats [[Myrtle McAteer]] 6–4 3–6 7–5 2–6 6–2 '''Davis Cup''' * 1901 International Lawn Tennis Challenge – {{davis|USA|1896}} walkover {{davis|GBR|name=British Isles}}
==[[Yacht racing]]== '''America's Cup''' * The [[New York Yacht Club]] retains the [[America's Cup]] as ''[[Columbia (1899 yacht)|Columbia]]'' defeats British challenger ''Shamrock II'', of the [[Royal Ulster Yacht Club]], 3 races to 0
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Football club infobox | clubname = AS Excelsior | image = [[File:AS_Excelsior_Tahiti.png]]. | fullname = Association Sportive Excelsior Football | nickname = | founded = 1940 | ground = [[Stade Mission]]
[[Papeete]], [[Tahiti]], [[French Polynesia]] | capacity = 1,000 | chairman = Denise Yan [https://sites.google.com/site/asexcelsiortennis/] AS Excelsior Tennis | manager = | league = [[Tahiti Ligue 2]] | season = [[2017-18]] |position = 6st in [[2017-18 Tahiti Ligue 2|Ligue 2]] }} '''Association Sportive Excelsior Football''', is a [[sport]] club from [[Papeete]], [[Tahiti]]. The club has [[football (soccer)|football]] and [[tennis]] sections . The football team on several titles in the [[Football in Tahiti|Tahitian football]], mainly in the decades of 1950 and 1960. Today, they compete in the [[Tahiti Ligue 2]] the second tier of the football system in [[Tahiti]].[https://www.ftf.pf/ligue-2-2/], Fédération Tahitienne de Football ==Achievements== *'''[[Tahiti Ligue 1]]''': 7 :: 1952, 1956, 1957, 1959, 1960, 1986, 1988. *'''[[Tahiti Cup]]''': 4 :: 1960, 1963, 1964, 1965. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://sites.google.com/site/asexcelsiortennis/ AS Excelsior Tennis] *[https://www.facebook.com/ExcelsiorFootballTahiti/ Facebook Page] {{Tahiti Division Fédérale}} {{FrenchPolynesia-sport-stub}} {{Oceania-footyclub-stub}} [[Category:Tahitian football clubs]]

{{Infobox person | name = Adriana Monsalve | image= | caption = |birth_name=Adriana Monsalve | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1977|7|27}} | birth_place =[[Caracas]], [[Venezuela]]{{cite web|url=http://espnmediazone.com/us/bios/adriana-monsalve/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-10-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140726031443/http://espnmediazone.com/us/bios/adriana-monsalve/ |archivedate=2014-07-26 |df= }} | death_date = | death_place = | education = | occupation = Sportscaster
Journalist
[[Sports commentator|Television host]] | years_active = 2005– | alias = | title = | family = | spouse = | domesticpartner = | children = | relatives = | ethnicity = | salary = | networth = | credits = | agent = | URL = }} '''Adriana Monsalve''' (born July 27, 1977)http://es.starnostar.com/Adriana-Monsalve-Biografia-Adriana-Monsalve-Carrera-Perfil-Adriana-Monsalve-Biografia/35384/Biografia/ is a [[Venezuela]]n sportscaster, journalist who currently works for [[Univision Deportes]]. ==Career== Monsalve became famous as the lead singer in the girl band "Chikas" and in the pop bands "Tartara" in [[Venezuela]], and "Latin Fiesta" in [[London]], [[England]]. She also hosted the TV morning show "Aló RCTV" in [[Caracas]] for more than a year. In 2002, she moved to the [[United States]], where she has participated in many commercials and stage productions such as "Esther" at the [[Tampa Bay Performing Arts Center]]. Soon after, she became the Hispanic Spokesperson for furniture giant "Rooms to Go". In 2005, when she was hired to be the sports anchor for the 6:00 pm newscast of [[Orlando]]'s [[Telemundo]] local affiliate. In 2007 Monsalve was hired by ESPN as Sports Anchor of ESPN Deportes broadcasting for Sports' Center Hispanic viewers in [[North America]], and also through ESPN 2 Central and [[South America]].[http://www.adrianamonsalve.com/ Official website] On November 28, 2014, she announced she was leaving [[ESPN Deportes|ESPN]], and later revealed she was joining [[Univision Deportes]]. ==Sports Driver== * Alo RCTV 2000 - 2002 * Theatrical productions como Esther 2003 * Rooms to Go 2004 - 2005 * [[Telemundo]] 2005 - 2007 * [[ESPN Deportes|ESPN]] Sport Center 2007 - 2010 * [[ESPN Deportes|ESPN]] Nación ESPN 2011 - 2014 * [[Univision Deportes]] 2015 - ==References== {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Monsalve, Adriana}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Sports journalists]] [[Category:Venezuelan women journalists]] [[Category:1977 births]] [[Category:People from Caracas]] [[Category:Venezuelan expatriates in Mexico]]

The '''anchor leg''' is the final position in a [[relay race]]. Typically, the anchor leg of a relay is given to the fastest or most experienced competitor on a team. The athlete completing the anchor leg of a relay is responsible for making up ground on the race-leader or preserving the lead already secured by their teammates.<ref>[http://www.runnersworld.com/running-tips/ask-coaches-relay-strategy Ask the Coaches: Relay Strategy]. ''[[Running Times]]'' (2002-07-02). Retrieved on 2014-05-23.</ref> An anchor leg is typically part of a [[running]] relay, but may also be part of [[swimming (sport)|swimming]], [[skiing]] or [[skating (disambiguation)|skating]] relays.<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/keyword/anchor-leg Anchor Leg]. ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''. Retrieved on 2014-05-23.</ref><ref>[http://www.swimmingworldmagazine.com/lane9/news/college/38365.asp Missy Franklin's Unreal Anchor Leg Secures 800 Free Relay Victory for California] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140523231228/http://www.swimmingworldmagazine.com/lane9/news/college/38365.asp |date=May 23, 2014 }}. ''[[Swimming World]]'' (2014-03-21). Retrieved on 2014-05-23.</ref>
==Famous anchor leg runners==
"Bullet" [[Bob Hayes]] ran anchor leg for the United States [[4×100 metres relay]] team in the [[1964 Tokyo Olympics]]. Receiving the baton in fifth place, Hayes pulled ahead of four runners to win the race. A French rival, [[Jocelyn Delecour]], remarked to the American lead-off runner [[Paul Drayton (athlete)|Paul Drayton]] "You haven't got anything except Hayes", and Drayton responded "That's all we need, pal".<ref>Litsky, Frank (2002-09-20). [https://www.nytimes.com/2002/09/20/sports/bob-hayes-stellar-sprinter-and-receiver-is-dead-at-59.html Bob Hayes, Stellar Sprinter and Receiver, Is Dead at 59 ]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. Retrieved on 2014-05-23.</ref>
[[Carl Lewis]] never lost a race when he anchored the American 4×100 m relay team. He regularly ran under 9 seconds for his anchor legs and helped the team break the [[Men's 4 × 100 metres relay world record progression|world record in the 4×100 m relay]] five times. The record set by the U.S. at the [[1992 Summer Olympics]] of 37.40 seconds stood for 16 years.
Anchoring the U.S. sprint relay team at the [[1984 Summer Olympics]], [[Evelyn Ashford]] ran a reported 9.77 seconds, the fastest time ever for a woman over 100 metres. The U.S. team of [[Alice Brown (athlete)|Alice Brown]] (first leg), [[Jeanette Bolden]] (second leg) and [[Chandra Cheeseborough]] (third leg) won by the biggest margin in the event's history.
[[Usain Bolt]] anchored the 2012 Jamaican 4x100 metres relay and helped set a new world record with a time 36.84 seconds.
In some cases, athletes who are not top performers in individual events excel when given the responsibility of anchoring a relay. [[Phil Brown (athlete)|Phil Brown]], a U.K. [[400 metres|400 m]] runner, won Olympic, World and European championship medals as the anchor leg runner for his national [[4 x 400 metres relay|4 x 400 m relay]] team despite never having won a medal and rarely having advanced beyond the preliminary rounds individually, while British hurdling specialist [[Kriss Akabusi]] swapped places with normal Great Britain anchor, Olympic 400 metre silver medalist [[Roger Black]] in a race where he famously caught, held and then passed 400 metre world champion [[Antonio Pettigrew]] to win Great Britain the [[2007 World Championships in Athletics|World Championship gold in Tokyo]], the United States' only championship loss at the distance in a 12 year span. Due to the final legs of 4 x 400 metre relay being run without lanes, the anchor may need to display some of the talents normally associated with a middle distance runner, including tactical awareness, overtaking technique and physical strength to hold off other athletes, as well as basic speed.
After she placed 8th individually in the [[100 metres|100 m]], [[Pam Marshall]] ran the anchor leg for the American 4 x 100 m team at the [[1987 World Athletics Championships]] in Rome and beat [[Marlies Göhr]] in the final with an anchor leg timed at 10.11 s to Gohr's 10.41 s.

== Famous anchor leg swimmers==
At the 2008 Summer Olympics in Beijing, [[Jason Lezak]] was the oldest male on the U.S. swim team. He anchored the U.S. 4×100 m freestyle relay team that won the gold medal and set a new world record.
At the 2012 Summer Olympics in London, [[Michael Phelps]] swam the anchor leg of the 4 x 200 m relay becoming the most decorated Olympian of all time with his 19th career medal (15th gold medal). He returned in 2016 to again anchor the [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 4 × 200 metre freestyle relay|4x200]], claiming his 21st gold and 25th medal.

{{Infobox cycling team | name = Bankgiroloterij | image = | code = | registered = [[Netherlands]] | founded = {{start date|2000}} | disbanded = 2004 | generalmanager = | teammanager = | discipline = [[Road bicycle racing|Road]] | status = | bicycles = | season = 2000-2003
2004 | oldname = Bankgiroloterij-Batavus
Bankgiroloterij | kitimage = | current = }} '''BankGiroLoterij''' was the name of a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] professional [[road bicycle racing]] team. The main sponsor from 2000 to 2004 was a Dutch lottery operator [[:nl:BankGiro Loterij|BankGiro Loterij]] {{nl icon}}. No sponsor was available for 2005, so the team disbanded. At that time, they were placed 29th in Division 1 in the [[UCI Road World Rankings]]. A significant number of the team riders joined Team [[Team Giant-Alpecin|Shimano-Memory Corp]], after its merge with [[Japan]]ese team [[Shimano]]. ==References== *[http://www.trap-friis.dk/cykling/archive-2004tt1.htm Trap-Friis.dk] (team data) [[Category:Defunct cycling teams based in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Cycling teams based in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Cycling teams established in 2000]] [[Category:Cycling teams disestablished in 2004]] [[Category:2004 disestablishments in the Netherlands]] [[Category:2000 establishments in the Netherlands]] {{cycling-team-stub}} {{Netherlands-sport-stub}}

{{unreferenced|date=March 2016}} {{EngvarB|date=May 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} The '''Buffs''' ({{zh|t=巴符/巴付陸軍}}) was an association football team formed of players from the [[Buffs (Royal East Kent Regiment)|Royal East Kent Regiment]]. It played in [[Hong Kong First Division League]] in the past. The team is now dissolved.
The Buffs is the first champion of [[Hong Kong First Division League]].
==Honours== * '''[[Hong Kong First Division League]]''' ** '''Winners (2)''': [[1908–09 Hong Kong First Division League|1908–09]], 1910–11
==See also== * [[Buffs (Royal East Kent Regiment)]] * [[Hong Kong First Division League]] * [[List of Hong Kong football champions]]
{{HongKong-footyclub-stub}}

{{Infobox football club | clubname = Carara Kicks | image = Carara Kicks FC logo.svg | upright = 0.9 | fullname = Carara Kicks Football Club | nickname = | founded = 2000 | ground = [[Goble Park]], [[Bethlehem, Free State|Bethlehem]] | capacity = 20,000 | chairman = Motebang Mokoena | manager = {{flagicon|Zimbabwe}} [[William Mugeyi]] | league = [[National First Division]] | season = | position = | pattern_la1=|pattern_b1=|pattern_ra1=| leftarm1=FF0000|body1=FF0000|rightarm1=FF0000|shorts1=FF0000|socks1=FF0000| pattern_la2=|pattern_b2=|pattern_ra2=| leftarm2=FFFFFF|body2=FFFFFF|rightarm2=FFFFFF|shorts2=FFFFFF|socks2=FFFFF| }} '''Carara Kicks''' are a [[South Africa]]n [[football (soccer)]] club based in [[Welkom]], [[Free State (South African province)|Free State]] that participates in the [[National First Division]].
The club is owned by [[Motebang Mokoena]], the son of [[Free State Stars]] owner [[Mike Mokoena]] and serves as a feeder team to Stars who play in the [[Premier Soccer League]].

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Coca-Cola Coliseum | other_names = | logo_image = Coca-Cola_Coliseum.png | image = Ricohcoliseum.jpg | nickname = | address = 45 Manitoba Drive | location = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada | coordinates = {{coord|43|38|08.27|N|79|24|54.14|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = 1920 | built = | opened = December 16, 1921 | closed = | demolished = | renovated = 1963, 1997, 2003 | owner = [[City of Toronto]] | operator = [[Maple Leaf Sports & Entertainment]] | construction_cost = {{CAD|link=yes}}1 million
$3 million (1963 renovation)
$38 million (2003 renovation) | architect = George F.W. Price (original){{cite web |title=Coliseum Complex, Exhibition Place - G.F.W. Price, City Architect|url=http://www.torontohistory.org/Pages_ABC/Coliseum_Complex.html|publisher=Toronto History|accessdate=June 11, 2014}}
Brisbin Brook Beynon, Architects (renovation) | general_contractor = | former names = {{Plainlist| * CNE Coliseum (1921–2003) * Royal Coliseum{{sfn|Filey|1996|p=72}} * Ricoh Coliseum (2003–2018) * Toronto Coliseum (July 2015)}} | tenants = [[Toronto-Buffalo Royals]] ([[World TeamTennis|WTT]]) (1974)
[[Toronto Marlies]] ([[American Hockey League|AHL]]) (2005–present)
[[Toronto Triumph]] ([[Lingerie Football League|LFL]]) (2011–2012)
[[Toronto Roadrunners]] ([[American Hockey League|AHL]]) (2003–2004) | seating_capacity = [[Ice hockey]] 7,851;{{cite web |title=Staff Directory|url=http://www.marlies.ca/team/StaffDirectory.asp|publisher=Toronto Marlies|accessdate=June 11, 2014}} 8,300 (including standing room){{cite web |title=Seating Capacity|url=https://www.newswire.ca/news-releases/new-coca-cola-and-mlse-partnership-expands-commitment-to-the-community-through-coca-cola-coliseum-687890611.html|publisher=Maple Leafs Sports & Entertainment press release|accessdate=July 11, 2018}}
Concerts 9,250 | publictransit = [[Exhibition GO Station]]
[[Exhibition Loop]] }} '''Coca-Cola Coliseum''' is an arena at [[Exhibition Place]] in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada, used for agricultural displays, [[ice hockey]] and trade shows. It was built for the [[Canadian National Exhibition]] (CNE) and the [[Royal Agricultural Winter Fair]] (the Royal) in 1921. It was formerly known as the '''Ricoh Coliseum''', and since 1997 it has been part of the "National Trade Centre" exhibition complex. It serves as the home arena of the [[Toronto Marlies]] ice hockey team, the [[American Hockey League]] farm team of the [[Toronto Maple Leafs]]. For the [[2015 Pan American Games]] the venue hosted the [[Gymnastics at the 2015 Pan American Games|gymnastics competitions]] and was known as the '''Toronto Coliseum'''.{{cite news |last=Gilbert |first=Erika |date=July 15, 2015 |title=Guide to the 2015 Pan Am Games: Everything you need to know about artistic gymnastics |url=http://news.nationalpost.com/sports/guide-to-the-2015-pan-am-games-everything-you-need-to-know-about-artistic-gymnastics |newspaper=[[National Post]] |location=Toronto, Ontario, Canada |access-date=August 9, 2015 }} ==History== On January 1, 1920, Toronto voters approved by plebiscite{{cite news |work=Toronto World |date=January 2, 1920 |title=Total Vote Polled For Mayor, Controllers And Bylaws |page=4}} a proposal by the Royal Agricultural Fair Association to construct, at a maximum cost of {{CAD|1|link=yes}} million, a new arena for livestock. The [[Municipal government of Toronto|City of Toronto]] (City) made a call for tenders in the fall of 1920 but the lowest tender was {{CAD|1.9}} million, exceeding the mandate approved by plebiscite. The size of the planned building was reduced by half in an attempt to get the cost under {{CAD|1}} million and a new call for tenders was done.{{cite news |work=The Globe |date=April 15, 1921 |title=Change In Size of Fair Arena |page=8}} The lowest tender received was from Anglin-Norcross Ltd. of Montreal for {{CAD|892,000}} to build the building to City Architect F. W. Price's specifications. There was reticence to hire a Montreal firm, and the city held off on awarding the contract while Price sought out construction offers from local firms to do the work using day labour, although the legality of this was questioned.{{cite news |work=Toronto Star |date=May 6, 1921 |page=1 |title=City Architect Is Told To Build Live Stock Arena}} Another issue raised was that the revised arena design needed to be expanded to meet the fair's needs. Anglin-Norcross offered to do the work at a further {{CAD|31,000}}. It took two City Council votes, but Council finally approved the awarding of the contract to Anglin-Norcross on May 26, 1921.{{cite news |work=Toronto Star |date=May 27, 1921 |title=Arena Contracts Are Debated by City Council |page=1}} Demolition of existing buildings on the site commenced a few days later and arena work commenced in June 1921.{{cite news |work=Toronto Star |title=Pay Cut-Rate Wages On Arena Contracts? |date=June 29, 1921 |page=19}} The cornerstone was laid by Toronto Mayor [[Thomas Langton Church|Thomas Church]]{{cite web |publisher=Toronto Public Library |url=http://www.torontopubliclibrary.ca/detail.jsp?R=DC-PICTURES-R-4119 |title=C.N.E.; Coliseum, laying of cornerstone by T. L. Church. Toronto, Ont.|accessdate=August 14, 2015}} on July 27, 1921 and Robert Fleming, President of the [[Canadian National Exhibition]] (CNE) declared that the building would be the largest of its kind in the world,{{cite web |work=The Globe |date=July 28, 1921 |title=Mayor Well And Truly Lays Corner-Stone Of New Arena |page=6}} with a floor space of {{Convert|8.5|acre|ha}}.{{cite news |work=Toronto Star |date=July 27, 1921 |title=New Live Stock Arena Assuming Shape |page=3}} [[File:Exhibition Coliseum under construction 1921.jpg|thumb|left|Construction of the arena in October 1921. The building was later opened in December 1921.]] The Fair Association had hoped for the arena to be open by the fall of 1921 to inaugurate the new fair, but it was not ready. The {{CAD|1}} million building had its official public opening on December 16, 1921, attended by 5,000 persons to see an athletic meet put on by the "Sportsmen Patriotic Association."{{cite news |work=Toronto Star |date=December 17, 1921 |page=3 |title=5,000 People Attend Opening of New Arena}} Upon completion, the building was billed as the largest of its kind in North America.{{cite web |title=Walking Tours |url=http://www.explace.on.ca/history/walking_tours.php |publisher=Exhibition Place |accessdate=October 6, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150906122050/http://www.explace.on.ca/history/walking_tours.php |archivedate=September 6, 2015 |df= }} The name "Coliseum" was given to the building in 1922, in time for the opening of the CNE.{{cite news |work=Toronto Globe |title=Council To Consider Rental of Coliseum |date=July 8, 1922 |page=17}} The main entrance was to the north, along Manitoba Drive. The southern side of the building was along the main TTC streetcar rail lines serving the CNE, which separated the Coliseum and Industry Buildings to the north, and the later Engineering and Electrical Building (1928) to the south. In 1926, additions were built and the complex was claimed to be the largest structure of its kind under one roof in the world.{{cite web|url=http://openplaques.org/places/ca/areas/toronto_on/plaques?id=unphotographed |publisher=openplaques.org |title=Open Plaques: Toronto, ON, Canada: Unphotographed |accessdate=August 14, 2015}} In 1931, the [[Horse Palace]] was built next door to provide a permanent building for the stables of the Winter Fair.{{cite web |work=Toronto Star |title=New Million-Dollar Exhibition Stables Completed Tomorrow |page=24 |date=August 14, 1931}} [[File:Horse Judging in Coliseum, 1940.jpg|thumb|Horses are judged at the Coliseum in 1940. The building hosted a number of equestrian events since its completion.]] From 1942 to 1945, the building was used as a training base for the [[Royal Canadian Air Force]] during [[World War II]] and known as the 'Manning Depot'. A photo of it as the RCAF Manning Depot is in the New Westminster Museum and Archives # IHP9562-003. After the war, it mainly hosted equestrian events for the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair, the CNE and other events. The arena was also used as a horse barn. In time for the 1963 CNE, the southern facade was reconstructed.{{cite news |work=Toronto Star |title=World's Biggest, The CNE Just Another Month Away |date=July 17, 1963 |page=33}} As part of the renovation, the southern facade was reclad with black, grey and white siding and a new front plaza was built, with a large "COLISEUM" sign on top. The CNE spent {{CAD|3}} million from 1960 until 1963 on "face-lifting" the Coliseum.{{cite news |work=The Globe and Mail |date=August 23, 1963 |title=How Much Has The CNE Changed? |page=7 |first=Betty |last=Lee}} In 1997, the National Trade Centre (now the [[Enercare Centre]]) exhibition complex was built. The new project removed the 1963 entrance and cladding, restoring the original facade, although the cupola towers on the southern facade had been removed in the 1963 renovation. Access to the Coliseum was moved to the western entrance of the exhibition complex through a hall known as Heritage Court.{{cite news |first=Christopher |last=Hume |date=April 5, 1997 |title=Vast trade centre shows two faces |work=Toronto Star |page=M7}} In November 2002, the City of Toronto agreed to an extensive renovation of the Coliseum to attract a professional [[ice hockey]] team to the arena.{{cite news |title=AHL Team Back on Ice|first=Ken|last=Campbell|newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]|date=November 29, 2002}} At a cost of {{CAD|38}} million, the arena's capacity was expanded from 6,500 to 9,700 by building a new higher roof, lowering the floor, adding new seats in the expanded area and the installation of 38 private suites. [[OMERS#Borealis Infrastructure|Borealis Infrastructure]] contributed {{CAD|9}} million up front and {{CAD|20}} million of borrowed funds in return for a 49-year lease to the arena.{{cite web|title=Expansion of MLSEL Office Space in Ricoh Coliseum |url=http://www.explace.on.ca/database/rte/files/Item%2017-MLSEL.pdf|publisher=[[Exhibition Place]]|date=June 26, 2013 |accessdate=January 3, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140103154508/http://www.explace.on.ca/database/rte/files/Item%2017-MLSEL.pdf |archivedate=January 3, 2014|df=}} The City of Toronto invested {{CAD|9}} million in the project and guaranteed Borealis' loans, while remaining the owner of the building.{{cite news |title=Coliseum Gets Makeover |first=James|last=Christie |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/coliseum-gets-makeover/article1009714/ |newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]] |date=January 16, 2003 |accessdate=January 2, 2014}} In 2003, [[Japan]]ese office supply company [[Ricoh]] purchased the naming rights to the new facility for {{CAD|10}} million over ten years, with an optional five-year extension.{{cite press release |title=Ricoh Canada Inc. Announces the Opening of Toronto's Ricoh Coliseum |url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20031106005775/en/Ricoh-Canada-Announces-Opening-Torontos-Ricoh-Coliseum#.UsZBY_ggp2N |publisher=Ricoh Canada, Inc.|date=November 6, 2003|accessdate=January 2, 2014 |archiveurl=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Ricoh+Canada+Inc.+Announces+the+Opening+of+Toronto%27s+Ricoh+Coliseum.-a0109864185 |archivedate=November 6, 2003}} During the summer of 2015, a new scoreboard was installed at the [[Air Canada Centre]], and the old scoreboard was installed at the Coliseum.{{cite web |url=https://www.thestar.com/sports/leafs/2015/07/24/acc-to-debut-new-scoreboard-this-year.html |title=Air Canada Centre to debut new scoreboard this year |first=Raju|last=Mudhar|date=July 24, 2015|accessdate=July 24, 2015|newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]}} In 2018, MLSE announced that the [[Toronto Argonauts]] football operations offices and weight rooms would be relocated to Ricoh Coliseum in late June of that year.{{Cite news|url=https://www.tsn.ca/argonauts-to-relocate-football-operations-staff-1.1100509|title=Argonauts to relocate football-operations staff - Article - TSN|date=2018-05-31|work=TSN|access-date=2018-06-03}} On July 11, 2018, at the end of Ricoh's partnership with the building, [[Coca-Cola]] purchased the naming rights to the facility for 10 years, re-naming it "Coca-Cola Coliseum".{{Cite news|url=https://www.newswire.ca/news-releases/new-coca-cola-and-mlse-partnership-expands-commitment-to-the-community-through-coca-cola-coliseum-687890611.html|title=New Coca-Cola and MLSE Partnership Expands Commitment to the Community Through Coca-Cola Coliseum - Article - CISION|date=2018-07-11|work=CISION|access-date=2018-07-11}} ==Usage== Since November 1922, the Coliseum has been used by the [[Royal Agricultural Winter Fair]] held in November annually except during the years of [[World War II]]. The Fair uses the arena for the annual "Royal Horse Show" equestrian competition, as well as animal presentations. [[File:Toronto Royal Horse Show.jpg|thumb|The Royal Horse Show during the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair, an event hosted by the Coliseum.]] Each year in August, the Coliseum is used by the CNE for exhibits and performances. It has in the past used for CNE cat, dog and horse shows. Until 2013, the CNE held the CNE Horse Show, a competitive event in the Coliseum. At one time run during the Ex, it changed to be a pre-CNE event in 2005.{{cite news |work=Inside Toronto |url=http://www.insidetoronto.com/news-story/4192958-cne-cancels-horse-show-competition/ |title=CNE cancels Horse Show competition |accessdate=August 19, 2015}} It has been used by the [[Musical Ride|Royal Canadian Mounted Police Musical Ride]]. During the 2009, 2010 and 2011 CNE, it was used for a figure skating show. The arena is also used for trade shows. The annual Boat Show builds an indoor pond over the arena floor. ===Ice hockey=== As early as the 1970s, plans were floated to outfit CNE Coliseum for [[ice hockey]]. When the [[World Hockey Association]]'s [[Ottawa Nationals]] moved to Toronto as the [[Toronto Toros]], they initially wanted to play at a renovated CNE Coliseum. However, due to objections from Maple Leafs vice president [[Bill Ballard]], the Toros played at [[Varsity Arena]] before briefly becoming tenants of the Leafs at [[Maple Leaf Gardens]]. [[File:Calder Cup Final - (06.14.18)-37 (41216027430).jpg|thumb|[[2018 Calder Cup playoffs|2018 Calder Cup Final]] between the [[Texas Stars]] and the [[Toronto Marlies]]. The arena was outfitted for ice hockey in the early 21st century.]] In the early 2000s, there were efforts to bring a minor professional hockey team to the Coliseum. Plans to move the dormant [[Phoenix Roadrunners (IHL)|Phoenix Roadrunners]] of the [[International Hockey League (1945–2001)|International Hockey League]] to Toronto for the 2002-2003 season fell apart when the league dissolved and six teams, but not the Roadrunners, were absorbed by the [[American Hockey League]] (AHL) in the summer of 2001.{{cite news |title=Roadrunners' Future in the IHL Looks Pretty Grim ; Team's Hopes of Survival Seem to Be on Life Support|first=Ken|last=Campbell|newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]|date=June 1, 2001}}{{cite news |title=Deal with the City Had Its Skeptics|newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]|date=November 1, 2003}} The same group then attempted to purchase the [[Louisville Panthers]] AHL franchise, which had suspended operations for the 2001-2002 season, and relocate it to the Coliseum, but the AHL voted against the transaction in December 2001.{{cite news |title=Bulldogs at Centre of Louisville Relocation|first=Garry|last=Mckay|newspaper=[[The Hamilton Spectator]]|date=July 7, 2001}}{{cite news |title=Deal to Bring AHL to the CNE 'Close' ; Hamilton's Bulldogs Could Become the Toronto Roadrunners|first=Ken|last=Peters|newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]|date=April 3, 2002}} The [[Toronto Maple Leafs]] pressured the [[Hamilton Bulldogs (AHL)|Hamilton Bulldogs]], who held territorial rights to Toronto since it fell within their 50-mile home territory, to veto the transaction. The Leafs reportedly did not want the Coliseum to be upgraded as it would compete with their newly opened [[Air Canada Centre]]. Next, the group began pursuing the Bulldogs, which were owned by their NHL affiliate the [[Edmonton Oilers]]. The Bulldogs did not require league approval to move to Toronto since the Coliseum was within their territory.{{cite news |title=Hamilton Bulldogs Unleashed to Become Toronto Roadrunners: New Deal Will Save Oilers Several Million Dollars|first=Joanne|last=Ireland|newspaper=[[Edmonton Journal]]|date=April 18, 2002}}{{cite news |title=AHL Bulldogs Eyeing Move to Toronto|newspaper=[[Guelph Mercury]]|date=April 1, 2002}}{{cite news |title=Roadrunners Aim to Score at Box Office: Toronto's New Hockey Team Vows to Make Money|first=Robert|last=Thompson|newspaper=[[National Post]]|date=October 25, 2003}} An agreement was reached with the Oilers to relocate the Bulldogs to Toronto, and to rename them the [[Toronto Roadrunners]]. Borealis signed a 49-year sublease to the building with the Roadrunners for $9,500 per game. On November 1, 2003, the Coliseum made its debut as an ice hockey venue, as the Roadrunners tied the [[Rochester Americans]] 1-1. However, the Roadrunners' lease was terminated in June 2004, following their first season, for defaulting on its rent.{{cite news |title=Oilers' Farm Team Caught in Lease Controversy at Ricoh|first=Steve|last=Erwin|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/oilers-farm-team-caught-in-lease-controversy-at-ricoh/article1000820/|newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=June 16, 2004|accessdate=January 3, 2014}} The Oilers chose to [[Edmonton Road Runners|relocate]] the Roadrunners to [[Edmonton]] for the following season due to poor attendance and in anticipation of the impending [[2004–05 NHL lockout|NHL lockout]]. The Coliseum was left without a hockey tenant for a year, but in August 2004 [[Maple Leaf Sports & Entertainment]] announced that they would relocate their [[St. John's Maple Leafs|AHL farm team]] from [[St. John's, Newfoundland]] to Toronto to play in the Coliseum for the 2005-2006 season,{{cite web|title=Leafs Making Final Run in St. John's|url=http://theahl.com/leafs-making-final-run-in-st-john-s-p137005|publisher=[[American Hockey League]]|date=November 29, 2004|accessdate=January 3, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140103163121/http://theahl.com/leafs-making-final-run-in-st-john-s-p137005|archivedate=January 3, 2014|df=}} after agreeing on a 20-year lease for the arena. Their lease calls for rent to cover debt financing charges, property taxes and generate a return to the arena investors,{{cite web |title=Comprehensive Review of City's Loan Guarantee and Loan Portfolio|url=http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2013/ex/bgrd/backgroundfile-57447.pdf|publisher=City of Toronto|date=April 9, 2013|accessdate=January 3, 2014}} which exceeds $4 million annually.{{cite book |title=Dream Job|last=Peddie|first=Richard|year=2013|publisher=[[Harper Collins]]}} The team, which was subsequently renamed the [[Toronto Marlies]], debuted in their new home on October 12, 2005 with a 5-2 victory over the [[Syracuse Crunch]], in front of a crowd of 8,056. The Coliseum hosted the 2007 [[American Hockey League|AHL]] All-Star Game on January 29, 2007. ===Other sports=== [[File:Vault 4 2015 Pan Am Games.jpg|thumb|The Coliseum hosted the [[Gymnastics at the 2015 Pan American Games|gymnastics competition]] for the [[2015 Pan American Games]].]] On April 4, 1922, it was the site of the [[Johnny Dundee]] vs Jimmy Goodrich boxing match promoted by Jack Corcoran that set a new indoor sports attendance record for Toronto with 11,900 spectators packed into the building. The mark would stand until the construction of [[Maple Leaf Gardens]] in 1931. The Coliseum hosted the [[Lingerie Football League|Lingerie Football League's]] [[Toronto Triumph]] in their lone season in operation in 2012. From July 11–20, 2015, the Coliseum hosted the [[Gymnastics at the 2015 Pan American Games|gymnastics competition]] of the [[2015 Pan American Games]], during which it was known as the "Toronto Coliseum." The Coliseum hosted the Longines World Cup Jumping (Equestrian) Championships in November 2015. The Coliseum hosted the Canada-Netherlands [[Davis Cup]] tie September 14-16, 2018, which featured [[Daniel Nestor]]’s final competitive match. ===Concerts=== The Coliseum has been used for numerous musical concerts. Acts that have performed there include [[Jimi Hendrix]], [[The Doors]], [[The Who]], [[Genesis (band)|Genesis]], [[Bob Dylan]], [[Vanilla Fudge]], [[Mötley Crüe]]{{cite web |publisher=Ricoh Coliseum |url=https://www.setlist.fm/setlist/motley-crue/1984/cne-coliseum-toronto-on-canada-53d32305.html |title=Mötley Crüe Concert Setlist at C.N.E. Coliseum, Toronto on June 10, 1984}} and [[Kraftwerk]].{{cite web |publisher=Ricoh Coliseum |url=http://ricohcoliseum.com/about/history/ |title=History - Ricoh Coliseum}} From 1922 to 1934, the CNE's Canadian National Exhibition Chorus performed in the arena.{{cite web |publisher=The Canadian Encyclopedia |title=Canadian National Exhibition Chorus |url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/canadian-national-exhibition-chorus-emc/ |accessdate=August 18, 2015}} In 2007, the Coliseum hosted the first [[We Day]] concert.{{cite web |publisher=We Day |title=Evolution of a Movement |url=http://www.weday.com/what-is-we-day/our-story/evolution/ |accessdate=August 18, 2015}} The Philippine TV show [[ASAP (TV series)|ASAP]] performed in Toronto on July 29, 2017. ==See also== {{Commons category}} *[[List of indoor arenas in Canada]] *[[Venues of the 2015 Pan American and Parapan American Games]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} * |ref=harv}} ==External links== * [https://www.coca-colacoliseum.com/ Official web site] * [http://www.gettyimages.ca/detail/news-photo/boris-szmaka-steve-yarkun-admire-new-facade-for-cne-news-photo/502822199?Language=en-GB Picture of 1963 facade] {{Geographic Location | title = | North = [[Gardiner Expressway]] / [[Exhibition GO Station]] / [[Exhibition Loop (TTC)]] | East = [[Exhibition Place#Other buildings and structures|Princes' Gates]] | South = [[Enercare Centre]] | West = revision.comment: Fixed typo, Someone put "becomettyttt fart" in the paragraph irrelevantly.
revision.text:
Professionals and amateurs alike wear protective head gear (helmets) to reduce the chance of injury while playing [[American football]]. The [[football helmet]] has changed over time and many different materials have become available. The rules of the game have changed as well.
==Origins== [[File:Behind interference remington 1893.jpg|thumbnail|In the early days of American football, players did not wear helmets.]] In 1888 the [[college football]] rules convention voted to allow tackling below the waist. Players and coaches soon regarded pads as essential for the game. However, as in the [[National Hockey League]] during the 1970s, helmets were the last thing to be accepted.<ref>Gentile, D.J.; [http://digitalcommons.calpoly.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1043&context=comssp&sei-redir=1&referer=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com.au%2Fscholar%3Fq%3Dinvention%2B%2522football%2Bhelmet%2522%26btnG%3D%26hl%3Den%26as_sdt%3D1%252C5%26as_vis%3D1#search=%22invention%20football%20helmet%22 Ideological Criticism Of The National Football League's Increase In Helmet To Helmet Discipline]</ref> They were not a mandatory piece of equipment in college gridiron until 1939<ref name="nelson">Nelson, David M.; ''The Anatomy of a Game: Football, the Rules, and the Men Who Made the Game''; p. 76. {{ISBN|0874134552}}</ref> and were not made mandatory in the National Football League until [[1943 NFL season|1943]]<ref name="official">Beau Riffenburgh, ''The Official NFL Encyclopedia'': "The Helmet"</ref> As a side note, "the last NFL player to play in a game without a helmet was [[Dick Plasman]] an [[end (American football)|end]] for the [[Chicago Bears]] in 1940."<ref name="official"/> There is a photograph of him without one taken during the [[1940 NFL Championship Game]] in which Chicago defeated [[1940 Washington Redskins season|the Washington Redskins]] 73–0.
Before the invention of the football helmet, players would often grow their hair long, because they believed it would protect their heads. <ref>[http://fourwallspublishing.com/BlogMChaney/?p=629 The 1890s: Brain Risks Confirmed in American Football]</ref> The man largely credited with inventing the first helmet was [[George Barclay (baseball)|George Barclay]].<ref name="nelson"/> In 1896 he designed a headgear which soon became known as a "head harness". It had three thick leather straps forming a close fit around his head, made by a harness maker. Additionally, other sources credit the invention of the football helmet to [[Navy Midshipmen football|U.S. Naval Academy Midshipman]] [[Joseph M. Reeves]] (later to become the "Father of Carrier Aviation"), who had a protective device for his head made out of mole skin to allow him to play in the 1893 [[Army-Navy Game]] after he was told by a Navy doctor that he must give up football or risk death from another kick in the head. Reeves went to a local shoemaker/blacksmith and had a crude leather helmet fabricated to protect his skull.<ref>[http://www.militarymuseum.org/Reeves.html Californians and the Military: Admiral Joseph Mason "Bull" Reeves, USN (1872-1948)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091021110425/http://www.militarymuseum.org/Reeves.html |date=2009-10-21 }}</ref> Before the first helmet, Edgar Allan Poe III (grandnephew of [[Edgar Allan Poe|the famous writer]]) developed a small leather nose protector which, however, was found to severely interfere with vision and breathing and to come off easily<ref>"Equipment; in "Rielly, Edward J.; ''Football: An Encyclopedia of Popular Culture''; p. 106. {{ISBN|0803290128}}</ref> [[File:1909_Michigan-Minnesota.png|thumbnail|In the early 20th century, some players wore helmets but they were not mandatory.]] Later helmets were made of padded leather, and resembled aviators' helmets. The helmet slowly began to take more of the appearance we recognize today when around 1915 more padding and flaps were added with ear holes for better on-field communication. Painted helmets have been around almost as long as helmets themselves: used to show team spirit and to help the quarterback distinguish a down field receiver from the defenders. The helmets of the [[Michigan Wolverines football|University of Michigan Wolverines]] bear logos that follow the original seams of the leather helmets. Professional team logos started in 1948 when [[Fred Gehrke]], a [[Halfback (American football)|halfback]] for [[1948 Los Angeles Rams season|the Los Angeles Rams]], began painting a horn design on all of the Rams' helmets. Gehrke studied art at the [[University of Utah]].
The next innovation came probably in 1917 in the form of suspension: to "cradle" the skull away from the foam shell. Straps of fabric formed a pattern inside the helmet. They absorbed and distributed the impact better, and they allowed for ventilation. It was a breakthrough. They were first known as "ZH" or Zuppke helmets named after the [[Illinois Fighting Illini football|Illinois]] [[Robert Zuppke|coach who came up with the design]]. [[Rawlings (company)|Rawlings]] and [[Spalding (sports equipment)|Spalding]] were some of the first manufacturers.
The first person to design a bar face mask on a football helmet was Vern McMillan, the owner of a sporting goods store in [[Terre Haute, Indiana]]. It was a rubber-covered wire mask on a leather helmet. This kind was used in the mid-1930s.
==Plastic helmets== The plastic football helmet came in 1940. It was invented and patented by John T. Riddell and his son John T. Riddell Jr., of the John T. [[Riddell Sports Group, Inc.|Riddell]] Company in Chicago, a sporting goods provider. The single molded shell was stronger, lighter, longer-lasting, and did not rot the way leather does when damp. Colors could also be baked into the plastic so the paint jobs would be longer-lasting. In 1940 Riddell also developed the first chin strap to rest on the chin instead of the neck <!-- the chin strap had been resting on the adams apple, many thought this caused kneck injuries --> and the first plastic face mask.
There were problems however. The plastic helmets were brittle when hit head on. And the bar hole that was drilled for the face mask tended to pop loose. Because of this Riddell was in trouble and so was the plastic helmet. Riddell's plastic helmet was a little flat on top at first but it changed to its tear-drop shape, which allowed a blow to slide to one side or the other rather than be met head-on. Its web suspension could be raised or lowered to fit the head of a player.
In 1955, G.E. Morgan, a consultant to Riddell, and [[Paul Brown]], the coach of the [[Cleveland Browns]], invented the BT-5 face mask which is the single bar design. The year after the BT-5 a single wave radio was installed in a players helmet so the coach could give the play to the quarterback over a radio frequency. It only resulted in game time interference but the experiment was ahead of its time.
In 1971, Morgan, now chairman of the board of Riddell received a patent for "Energy Absorbing and Sizing Means for Helmets." The result: new HA-91 and HA-92 energy-absorbing, "microfit" helmets. They had valves on their crown to allow air to be pumped into vinyl cushions that were crammed into every space inside the helmet. The player put it on and then had it pumped up to fit firmly around the player's head. Sometimes fluid was also used. An anti-freeze solvent, was used by some of the [[Green Bay Packers]] to beat the cold of [[Lambeau field]].
Sources are unsure as to who first designed air bladders for football helmets but Dr. Richard Schneider of the [[University of Michigan]] Hospital is reported to have believed that air was the most effective way to protect against blunt force. With this theory in mind, he invented an inflatable bladder for use inside a football helmet. The Michigan Wolverines Football team used a prototype and [[Schutt Sports]] hired Schnieder and started mass-producing the AirTm Helmet in the early 1970s.
Many veteran players still preferred the old web suspended Riddell TK-2 because it was generally lighter and more breathable. Interior helmet pads were then developed that were lighter and did not need to be filled with air or fluid by both the Schutt and Riddell sports companies. And because of safety they were soon preferred by all positions {{source needed|date=June 2018}}.
In late 1976, because of concern for safety, four point chin straps were required in college ball. These kept the helmet firmly in place.
Space age rigid [[Polycarbonate]] alloy plastic helmets and vinyl coated steel alloy face masks were the norm in the 1980s and 1990s.
In 2002 Riddell released a new more spherical design for the helmet called the Revolution (or Revo) and it is currently the most widely used helmet in the [[National Football League]] The Schutt counterpart is called the DNA Pro Adult Helmet. A study released by the [[University of Pittsburgh Medical Center]] shows that the Riddell Revolution, and others like it, reduce the incidences of concussion by 31%.<ref>University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, Jan. 14, 2006, Science Daily Magazine: Newer Football Helmet Design May Reduce Incidence Of Concussions In High School Players, Shows University Of Pittsburgh Study.</ref> Subsequently, a Senate Commerce Committee meeting on October 19, 2011, heard testimony from Jeffrey Kutcher, an associate professor of neurology at the University of Michigan and chair of the American Academy of Neurology's sports neurology section that "there is no significant data" in the UPMC study for Riddell to make the claim that the helmet reduced concussions by 31%. On or about May 2013, Mary K. Engle, the FTC's associate director for advertising practices wrote that the agency had concluded the UPMC study "did not prove that Revolution varsity football helmets reduce concussions or the risk of concussions by 35%". Riddell has since discontinued use of the 31% claim. <ref>{{cite book|last=Fainaru-Wada|first=Mark|title=League of Denial|year=2013|publisher=Crown Archetype|location=New York|isbn=978-0-7704-3754-1|pages=317-318}}</ref> Later, Riddell released the Revolution Speed helmet.
== References == {{reflist}} {{Gridiron football equipment}} [[Category:Helmets]] [[Category:Protective gear]] [[Category:History of Canadian football]] [[Category:American football equipment]]

{{refimprove|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = JA Cotonou| image = | fullname = Jeunesse Athlétique du Cotonou| nickname = | founded = | ground = [[Stade Jean-Pierre Gascon]]
[[Cotonou]], [[Benin]] | capacity = 5,000| chairman = | manager = | league = [[Benin Premier League]] | season = 2013| position = 1st| }} '''Jeunesse Athlétique du Cotonou''' is a [[association football|football]] club in [[Benin]], playing in the town of [[Cotonou]]. They play in the Beninese first division, the [[Benin Premier League]].[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/benin/jeunesse-athletique-du-plateau/17208/] The club were previously known as '''Jeunesse Athlétique du Plateau''' and played in [[Pobe]], a city in the Plateau Department of Benin.{{cite web|title=Benin 2016|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesb/benin2016.html|website=www.rsssf.com|accessdate=13 November 2016}} ==Stadium== Currently the team plays at the 5,000 capacity [[Stade Jean-Pierre Gascon]]. ==Honours== * [[Benin Premier League]]: 2012–13 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/benin/jeunesse-athletique-du-plateau/17208/ Soccerway] {{Benin Premier League}} [[Category:Football clubs in Benin]] {{Benin-footyclub-stub}}

{{Infobox football club | clubname = JS Djijel | image = JS Djidjel.png | image_size = 150px | fullname = Jeunesse Sportive Djijelienne | nickname = En-nemra | founded = 12 March [[1936 in association football|1936]]
(as ''Jeunesse Sportive Djidjelienne'') | ground = [[Rouibah Hocine Stadium]] | capacity = 35,000 | chrtitle = President | chairman = [[Lyès Aïssani]] | mgrtitle = Head Coach | manager = [[Zahredine Bouridan]] | league = [[Ligue Nationale du Football Amateur]] | season = [[2017–18 Ligue Nationale du Football Amateur|2017–18]] | position = Ligue Nationale du Football Amateur, Group Centre, '''13th''' | current = 2018–19 JS Djijel season |pattern_la1=_hannover1112a |pattern_b1=_joma_greenhalfarc |pattern_ra1=_hannover1112a |pattern_sh1=_civ1012a |pattern_so1=_adidas_thick_stripes_green |leftarm1=ffffff |body1=FFFFFF |rightarm1=ffffff |shorts1=000000 |socks1=FFFFFF |pattern_la2 = _fcnord1112t |pattern_b2 = _joma_whitehalfarc |pattern_ra2 = _fcnord1112t |pattern_sh2 = _civ1012a |pattern_so2 = _2_white_stripes |leftarm2 = 00a008 |body2 = 00a008 |rightarm2 = 00a008 |shorts2 = |socks2 = 00a008 }} '''Jeunesse Sportive Djijelienne''' ({{lang-ar|الشباب الرياضي لجيجل}}), known as '''JS Djijel''' or simply '''JSD''' for short, is an Algerian football club based in [[Jijel]]. The club was founded in 1936 and its colours are green and white. Their home stadium, [[Rouibah Hocine Stadium]], has a capacity of 35,000 spectators. The club is currently playing in the [[Ligue Nationale du Football Amateur]].http://www.en-nemra.com/ JS Djijel is the leading football club in the city of [[Jijel]]. It is also one of the first football clubs created in the city in 1936. The club's glory days were in the 1970s with good players such as [[Carlos Lehtihet]], [[Boubezari]], [[Aberkane]] ... ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.en-nemra.com/ Official website] {{Ligue Inter-Régions}} {{Algerian Ligue Professionnelle 1}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Djijel, JS}} [[Category:Football clubs in Algeria]] [[Category:Jijel Province]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1936]] [[Category:1936 establishments in Algeria]] [[Category:Sports clubs in Algeria]] {{Algeria-footyclub-stub}}

{{Infobox Officeholder |honorific-prefix = The Right Honourable |name = Joseph Onika |honorific-suffix = [[Member of Parliament|MP]] |image = |office = Minister for Lands, Housing and Survey |primeminister = [[Danny Philip]] (until 16 November 2011);
then [[Gordon Darcy Lilo]] |term_start = 18 April 2011 |term_end = |predecessor = [[Martin Sopage]] |successor = |office2 = Minister for Women, Youth & Children’s Affairs |term_start2 = 27 August 2010 |term_end2 = 18 April 2011 |primeminister2 = Danny Philip |predecessor2 = |successor2 = [[Dickson Mua]] |office3 = |deputy3 = |term_start3 = |term_end3 = |predecessor3 = |successor3 = |office4 = |leader4 = |term_start4 = |term_end4 = |predecessor4 = |successor4 = |constituency_MP5 = [[East Central Guadalcanal constituency|East Central Guadalcanal]] |term_start5 = 4 August 2010 |term_end5 = |predecessor5 = [[Nollen Cornelius Leni]] |successor5 = |majority5 = |constituency_MP6 = |parliament6 = |term_start6 = |term_end6 = |predecessor6 = |successor6 = |birth_date = May 2, 1967 |birth_place = Komunima’aga, [[Guadalcanal Province]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Independent (politician)|Independent]] |alma_mater = |website = }} {{MedalTableTop}} {{MedalSport | Men's [[Track and field athletics|athletics]]}} {{MedalCountry | {{SOL}} }} {{MedalCompetition|[[Oceania Athletics Championships|Oceania Championships]]}} {{MedalGold |[[1990 Oceania Athletics Championships|1990 Suva]] | 100 m}} {{MedalSilver |[[1990 Oceania Athletics Championships|1990 Suva]] | 200 m}} {{MedalBottom}} '''Joseph Onika''' (born May 2, 1967 in Komunima’aga Village, Longu District, [[Guadalcanal Province]][http://www.parliament.gov.sb/index.php?q=node/520 Biography] on the website of the Parliament of Solomon Islands) is a [[Solomon Islands]] politician. ==Career== He worked in [[catering]] before going into politics. His career in national politics began when he was elected to [[Parliament of Solomon Islands|Parliament]] as the member for [[East Central Guadalcanal constituency|East Central Guadalcanal]] in the [[Solomon Islands general election, 2010|August 2010 general election]], standing as an [[independent (politician)|independent candidate]]. He was then appointed Minister for Women, Youth and Children’s Affairs in Prime Minister [[Danny Philip]]'s [[Cabinet of Solomon Islands|Cabinet]].[http://www.sibconline.com.sb/elections/results_party.asp?partyID=01 2010 election data] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101220080456/http://www.sibconline.com.sb/elections/results_party.asp?partyID=01 |date=2010-12-20 }}, [[Solomon Islands Broadcasting Corporation]] In April 2011, he was reshuffled to Minister for Lands, Housing and Survey.[http://solomontimes.com/news.aspx?nwID=6064 "New Cabinet Ministers Sworn in"], ''Solomon Times'', April 19, 2011 When [[Gordon Darcy Lilo]] replaced Philip as Prime Minister in November 2011, Onika retained his position in government.[http://www.solomonstarnews.com/news/national/12881-ten-more-ministers-sworn-in "Ten more ministers sworn in"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111124053721/http://www.solomonstarnews.com/news/national/12881-ten-more-ministers-sworn-in |date=2011-11-24 }}, ''Solomon Star'', 23 November 2011 == Achievements == He was successfully competing in [[Track and field athletics|athletics]]. {{ Citation| last =| first =| date =August 12, 2010| title =Solomon Islands fastest man elected into Parliament| url =http://www.vanuatunews.com/regional-news/region-sport/287-solomon-islands-fastest-man-elected-into-parliament-| publisher =vanuatunews.com| pages =| language =| accessdate =February 7, 2014| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20110901082849/http://www.vanuatunews.com/regional-news/region-sport/287-solomon-islands-fastest-man-elected-into-parliament-| archivedate =September 1, 2011| df =}} {| {{AchievementTable|Event=yes|class=wikitable style="text-align:center; font-size: 90%;}} |- !bgcolor="#eeeeee" colspan="6"|Representing {{SOL}} |- |rowspan=2|1990 |rowspan=2|[[1990 Oceania Athletics Championships|Oceania Championships]] |rowspan=2|[[Suva]], [[Fiji]] |bgcolor=gold|1st |100 m |10.75 s |- |bgcolor=silver|2nd |200 m |21.87 s |} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Onika, Joseph}} [[Category:1967 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the National Parliament of the Solomon Islands]] [[Category:People from Guadalcanal Province]] [[Category:Government ministers of the Solomon Islands]] [[Category:Solomon Islands male sprinters]] [[Category:Sportsperson-politicians]]

{{Korean name|Kim}} {{Infobox person |name = Kim Un-yong |image = Kim Unyong in 2012.jpg |image_size = 220 |birth_date = {{Birth date|1931|03|19|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Daegu]], [[South Korea]] |citizenship = {{flagicon|KOR}} [[Korean people|South Korean]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2017|10|3|1931|3|19|df=yes}} |traded_as = |occupation = Former president of the [[World Taekwondo Federation]]<ref name=S76>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=YNQDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA48&lpg=PA48&dq=kim+un-yong+taekwondo&source=bl&ots=VJ2Oj7hJ_q&sig=eSYdjV5MWk228CVQaIWa33Ye4Nw&hl=en&sa=X&ei=MSuWVLrVFYLWav3egbAD&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAzgK#v=onepage&q=kim%20un-yong%20taekwondo&f=false|title=Black Belt September 1976|website=Books.google.co.uk|accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=W9QDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA8&lpg=PA8&dq=kim+un-yong+world+taekwondo+federation&source=bl&ots=crRG3SHusd&sig=6is7p0s-rGvUP4s8Nn4UC3QGssA&hl=en&sa=X&ei=-SyWVMbNK8fgavGRgeAK&ved=0CDIQ6AEwBDgK#v=onepage&q=kim%20un-yong%20world%20taekwondo%20federation&f=false|title=Black Belt October 1977|website=Books.google.co.uk|accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://nwww.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20171003000060|title=Ex-IOC Vice President Kim Un-yong dead at 86|date=3 October 2017|website=Koreaherald.com|accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref> |relations = |spouse = |partner = |children = |alma_mater = [[Yonsei University]] |net_worth = | module = {{Infobox Korean name | hangul = 김운용 | hanja = 金雲龍 | rr = Gim Ullyong | mr = Kim Ullyong | child = yes }} | website = [http://www.kimunyong.com/ www.KimUnYong.com] }}
'''Kim Un-yong''' or '''Un Yong Kim''' (19 March 1931 – 3 October 2017) was a [[South Korea|South Korean]] sports administrator, Vice-President of the [[International Olympic Committee]], and founding member of the [[World Taekwondo Federation|WTF]] executive board.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/3771931.stm |title=IOC official jailed for corruption |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=2014-12-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/3293927.stm |title=S Korea Taekwondo chief held |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=2014-12-21}}</ref> Kim Un-yong was elected the president of the Korean Taekwondo Association on 23 January 1971.<ref name=KA>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Bd_NrWVI1q0C&pg=PT214&lpg=PT214&dq=kim+un-yong+world+taekwondo+federation&source=bl&ots=_cOrxUwVE2&sig=9lcQZZsZxdayJNA4NPGmBn2qtfQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=-SyWVMbNK8fgavGRgeAK&ved=0CEEQ6AEwCDgK#v=onepage&q=kim%20un-yong%20world%20taekwondo%20federation&f=false|title=A Killing Art|website=Books.google.co.uk|accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref> He received a doctorate in Political Science in 1963 from the [[Yonsei University]]. Kim retired from the WTF presidency in 2004 and was succeeded by Chungwon Choue.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/140188/kim-un-yong-resigns-from-top-ioc-post |title= Kim Un-yong resigns from top IOC post|publisher=[[Dawn]] |date= |accessdate=2014-12-21}}</ref>
Kim Un-yong was elected the president of the [[Korean Taekwondo Association]] on 23 January 1971. Though he initially declined the position due to the continued conflicts within the organization, he was asked by the Korean government to accept and to clean up the association.
Believing that Taekwondo was a Korean martial art and its governing body should therefore be based in Korea, Dr. Kim dissolved the relationship between the Korean Taekwondo Association and the [[International Taekwondo Federation]].
In 1973, the World Taekwondo Federation was formed and Dr. Kim was elected its first president.<ref name=mamw>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=CayyJJg0KIsC&pg=PA205&lpg=PA205&dq=kim+un-yong+taekwondo&source=bl&ots=KX3Q63xq9b&sig=U_gSfdoSEvC-OjnEFDzdc98yYYQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=hCyWVI6OLoTkat_DgegP&ved=0CCAQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=kim%20un-yong%20taekwondo&f=false|title=Martial Arts in the Modern World|publisher=}}</ref><ref name=M01>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ns4DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT73&lpg=PT73&dq=kim+un-yong+taekwondo&source=bl&ots=ndfo8vUVIJ&sig=U9aiSHl19gUb6Naad9wakY3fr_0&hl=en&sa=X&ei=XSyWVPu9OsL5ao_igmg&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAzge#v=onepage&q=kim%20un-yong%20taekwondo&f=false|title=Black Belt March 2001|website=Books.google.co.uk|accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref><ref name=S76/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=6toDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA29&lpg=PA29&dq=kim+un-yong+taekwondo&source=bl&ots=X77cSBrzqa&sig=KTq2-YUwFmuQrWJ0UhFiY4XKbC0&hl=en&sa=X&ei=4CuWVMWxDc7easOYgbgO&ved=0CFUQ6AEwCTg8#v=onepage&q=kim%20un-yong%20taekwondo&f=false|title=Black Belt October 1988|website=Books.google.co.uk|accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=FaTfuuIlmqcC&pg=PA203&lpg=PA203&dq=kim+un-yong+taekwondo&source=bl&ots=8yNMWUxc1y&sig=6hLhBbdfUN_OmpJgquq4hC1WO84&hl=en&sa=X&ei=7CuWVJ_2F8Lwauz0goAD&ved=0CCAQ6AEwADgy#v=onepage&q=kim%20un-yong%20taekwondo&f=false|title=Martial Arts of the World|website=Books.google.co.uk|accessdate=4 October 2017}}</ref>
In 2004 Kim was jailed for corruption and was responsible for getting taekwondo in the Olympics. {{ambiguous|date=August 2018}}<ref name=mamw/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2004/06/03/1086203549014.html |title=Olympic committee vice-president jailed for embezzlement |publisher=[[The Sydney Morning Herald|SMH]] |date= |accessdate=2014-12-21}}</ref><ref name=KA/>
Kim has served as President of the [[Korean Olympic Committee]], President of the 2002 Pusan Asian Games Organization Committee, President of the [[Korea Taekwondo Association]], President of World Taekwondo Headquarters ([[Kukkiwon]]), an Ambassador at Large with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Co-Chairman of the Rebuilding Korea Committee, and internationally, he was the President of [[GAISF]], Executive Board Member of the [[IOC]], Chairman of the IOC Radio and Television Commission, and President of the World Taekwondo Federation.<ref name=mamw/><ref name=M01/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.kimunyong.com/ Official website] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kim, Un-yong}} [[Category:1931 births]] [[Category:2017 deaths]] [[Category:South Korean politicians convicted of crimes]] [[Category:International Olympic Committee members]] [[Category:Sports executives and administrators]] [[Category:Yonsei University alumni]] [[Category:Prisoners and detainees of South Korea]] [[Category:South Korean male taekwondo practitioners]] [[Category:Members of the National Assembly (South Korea)]] [[Category:People from Daegu]]

[[Diana, Madagascar|Diana]], [[Madagascar]]| capacity = | chairman = | manager = | league = [[THB Champions League]] | season = 2013 | position = | }} '''Kohinoor Sporting Club''' is a Malagasy football club that currently plays in the [[THB Champions League]] the top division of Malagasy football.https://int.soccerway.com/teams/madagascar/kohinoor/25509/matches/ The team is based in the [[Diana, Madagascar|Diana]] in northern [[Madagascar]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ;General *[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/madagascar/kohinoor/25509/ Soccerway] *[http://es.fifa.com/world-match-centre/clubs/club=madagascar-kohinoor-sc-2000018668/index.html] [[Category:Football clubs in Madagascar]] {{Madagascar-footyclub-stub}}

revision.text:
The following is a description of the various and alternating rules of [[gridiron football]]. Numerous leagues or organizations tend to send a laundry list of rules in order to better distinguish themselves from their counterparts.
==American football (general)== {{main|American football rules}}
===Field and players=== American football is played on a field {{convert|360|by|160|ft|1}}.<ref name="Dimensions">{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsknowhow.com/football/field-dimensions/nfl-football-field-dimensions.html|title=NFL Football Field Dimensions|year=2004|publisher=SportsKnowHow.com|accessdate=2009-04-05}}</ref> The longer boundary lines are ''sidelines'', while the shorter boundary lines are ''end lines''. Sidelines and end lines are out of bounds. Near each end of the field is a ''goal line''; they are {{convert|100|yd|sigfig=3}} apart. A scoring area called an ''[[end zone]]'' extends {{convert|10|yd|sigfig=2}} beyond each goal line to each end line. The end zone includes the goal line but not the end line.<ref name="Dimensions" /> While the playing field is effectively flat, it is common for a field to be built with a slight crown—with the middle of the field higher than the sides—to allow water to drain from the field.
''Yard lines'' cross the field every {{convert|5|yd}}, and are numbered every 10 yards from each goal line to the 50-yard line, or midfield (similar to a typical [[rugby league]] field). Two rows of short lines, known as inbounds lines or ''hash marks'', run at 1-yard (91.4 cm) intervals perpendicular to the sidelines near the middle of the field. All plays start with the ball on or between the hash marks. Because of the arrangement of the lines, the field is occasionally referred to as a gridiron.
At the back of each end zone are two ''[[goalpost]]s'' (also called ''uprights'') connected by a crossbar {{convert|10|ft|m|sigfig=3}} from the ground. For high skill levels, the posts are {{convert|222|in|m|sigfig=3}} apart. For lower skill levels, these are widened to {{convert|280|in|m|sigfig=3}}.
Each team has 11 players on the field at a time. However, teams may substitute for any or all of their players, if time allows, during the break between plays. As a result, players have very specialized roles, and, sometimes (although rarely) almost all of the (at least) 46 active players on an NFL team will play in any given game. Thus, teams are divided into three separate units: the [[offensive team|offense]], the [[defensive team|defense]] and the [[special teams]].
===Start of halves=== Similarly to [[association football]], the game begins with a [[Coin flipping|coin toss]] to determine which team will kick off to begin the game and which goal each team will defend.<ref name="Toss">{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/rulebook/cointoss|title=Coin Toss|year=2009|publisher=NFL Enterprises LLC|accessdate=2009-04-05}}</ref> The options are presented again to start the second half; the choices for the first half do not automatically determine the start of the second half (i.e. it is possible for the same team to kick off both halves).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/rulebook/cointoss|title=Coin Toss|year=2009|publisher=NFL Enterprises LLC|accessdate=2015-01-18}} But, this ordinarily does not happen. Normally, the two halves are ''not'' both kicked off by the same team.</ref> The referee conducts the coin toss with the captains (or sometimes coaches) of the opposing teams. The team that wins the coin toss has three options:<ref name="Toss" /> # They may choose whether to kick or receive the opening kickoff. # They may choose which goal to defend. # They may choose to ''defer'' the first choice to the other team and have first choice to start the second half.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1A1-D8VQBFSG0.html| title=NFL Makes Some Rule Changes | year = 2008 | accessdate = 2008-04-03}}</ref> Whatever the first team chooses, the second team has the option on the other choice (for example, if the first team elects to receive at the start of the game, the second team can decide which goal to defend).
At the start of the second half, the options to kick, receive, or choose a goal to defend are presented to the captains again. The team which did not choose first to start the first half (or which deferred its privilege to choose first) now gets first choice of options.<ref name="Toss" /><ref name=NCAArules>{{cite web | url = https://www.ncaa.org/library/rules/2005/2005_football_rules.pdf |format=PDF| title = 2005 Rules and Interpretations | publisher = National Collegiate Athletic Association | year = 2005 | accessdate = 2008-01-09 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071129100253/http://www.ncaa.org/library/rules/2005/2005_football_rules.pdf |archivedate = 2007-11-29}}</ref>
===Game duration=== A standard football game consists of four 15-minute quarters (12-minute quarters in high-school football and often shorter at lower levels, usually one minute per grade [e.g. 9-minute quarters for freshman games]),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://football.calsci.com/TheRules4.html|title=The Field|last=Lawrence|first=Mark|date=2002–2005|publisher=Mark Lawrence|accessdate=2009-04-05}}</ref> with a 12-minute [[half-time]] intermission (30 minutes in [[Super Bowl]]) after the second quarter in the NFL (college halftimes are 20 minutes; in high school the interval is 15 or 20 minutes; 10 minutes for lower grades).<ref name="Beginner" /> The clock stops after certain plays; therefore, a game can last considerably longer (often more than three hours in real time), and if a game is broadcast on [[television]], [[Television timeout|TV timeouts]] are taken at certain intervals of the game to broadcast [[advertising|commercials]] outside of game action. If an NFL game is tied after four quarters, the teams play an additional period, timed like the fourth quarter, lasting up to 10 minutes. There is a coin toss in the NFL just like the beginning of the game. If the receiving team scores a touchdown during the possession, they win. If they kick a field goal, then the other team gets a possession. If they score a touchdown, they win. If they tie the score by kicking a field goal, then the next team that scores wins. If the team with the first possession turns the ball over without scoring any points, then the first team to score, wins. If the defense scores a touchdown through an interception or fumble recovery, or they get a safety, then they win. In a regular-season NFL game, if no one scores in the overtime, the game ends tied. In an NFL playoff game, multiple 15-minute overtime periods are played, as needed, to determine a winner. These periods are timed as if a game had started over. In the extremely rare case a game would go as far as a third OT—which has never happened in the NFL—there would be no "halftime intermission"; play would resume with a kickoff similar to a normal third quarter.
College overtime rules are more complicated and are described in [[Overtime (sport)]].
